I am not a huge fan of Minecraft like the crazy guys building 4bit computers but I do enjoy playing with it for a couple of years now.

I am also not a Microsoft hater - since I used Windows and other products for so many years - but I have to say they are pretty good at screw up games. (Age of Empires online, or the new app-clashoftitans-clone thingie).

The core team leaving Minecraft can end in two ways. Like have some fresh minds in the team might change the game.

The real problem is how Microsoft handle developments. And probably I don't want to see microtrans-actions in the game or, stupid facebook share as founding a diamond.

Maybe I am wrong and we will have never seen awesomeness in the game. But I am afraid that will be the end of an era for me...

title: My opinion about online code schools
content:
I believe no matter how good you are you can always learn something new so I try to find a useful online coding school.

I am interested in front-end courses of course and Ruby or PHP courses maybe some NoSQL. And since I already work as a dev I'd like to spend the money for real learning.
Badges are cool and I like nice design elements but absolutely not mandatory. Don't pay the 10 designer to draw little frogs (treehouse...) pay instead real teachers. (When I cancelled my subscription from CodeSchool I've got an email with a nicely designed animated car leaving... seriously...)

Ok so I got my budget for it and I know what I want but what is next?

I tried CodeSchool for 2 months (one month last year and one just now because I have 2*$5 discount)

At the first time I really liked it then I lost in the stupid songs. Got board that the actual tasks are only accept one solution (sometimes I don't agree with them)
So I have to use the hints to actually write the same stuff as they did just in a different format.
However there were a few really good course like the mastering git or try ruby.

My conclusion is that they put too much effort designing stuff. Their free courses are good but the paid ones are boring after a while. ($29/month)

Years ago I planned to sign up for Tree House but somehow I cannot handle the frogie thing and the hipsters on the front page learning in the park with a tablet. I wanted to try the trial but I don't understand why it they require my bankcard for that so no thank you. ($25 or $49/month)

Then we have CodeAcademy what is free and I just earned a badge actually click on the start button how cool I am :)
I playing the Ruby lesson and we are assigning numbers and strings for freaking 5 steps now but the advanced courses are very nice. I'll give a longer chance for it. (free)

Last one for front-end coders is Frontend Masters. I've read really positive reviews and the teachers are guys your really want to learn from. I don't like the price ($39/month). I can imagine that I pay by course. I'll give a shot probably in this year.

Online courses like CMS they want to be good for everyone but then focus on quantity rather then quality, or feeding the designers :)
I will write again about this topic when I tested the others as well.

title: Build your own grid #1
content:
This is an episode of my "You might not need framework" series

Do you know how easy to write a CSS grid system? Do you know it is just simple math?

People are afraid of touching css so they use bootstrap or foundation or something else, then start to overwrite the framework to fit into their project. Like I did several times. I was thinking hey why am I doing this? I wrote my first CSS in the 90's and still as first thing I reach for one of the well known (and just to make it clear really amazing) frameworks.

So I start to think and read then write my own grid. It took like 20 minutes or less. I spend some time on thinking how to name things.

Let's do the math. First we have the container. I preferred to keep it unset, only thing I did just call it grid. Bootstrap set it to 1170px wide but I want to set my own.
Next are the rows. 1 row is 1 full unit, that is 100%.
(You have set the grid to 1170px then that is you full unit that is your 100%). I called them lines but it can be easily renamed since it is my own CSS so I don't need to dig in the code.

Ok we have the container and we have the rows or lines.
In a row/line you can have max 12 units if you use a 12 grid system

There are 16 or 24 as well, but hey what if you want to have a 32 system, right?

I called unit u-X-Y. U stands for unit of course, X if the amount of Y. For example you want third of the row/line than you will add <div class="u-1-3"/> because you want to get a unit as 1/3 of 100%.
If you put 3 of them together then you will get a full row/line.

But how the hell are they stick together? Well we have float and clear.

Because of the box modelling you have to set up some global rules

*, *:after, *:before {
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

Set the container and the rows/lines

.grid {
  margin-right: auto;
  margin-left: auto;
  padding-right: 15px;
  padding-left: 15px;
}

.line {
  width: 100%;
}

.line:after {
  content: "";
  display: table;
  clear: both;
}

Then float all the units to the left and add padding as gutter but not to the last element.

[class*="u-"] {
  float: left;
  padding-right: 15px;
}

[class*="u-"]:last-of-type {
  padding-right: 0;
}

And last you start calculating your units. I did it one by one then I realised that I will have same rules so I merged them but again, it is you CSS do whatever you have to.

.u-1-1 { width: 100%; }
.u-1-2 { width: 50%; }
.u-1-3 { width: 25%; }

Got it? How about this:

Give me 1/1 of 100 = 100
Give me 1/2 of 100 = 50
Give me 1/3 of 100 = 25

When you go one by one you will see some of the unit make no sense like u-3-2. It will be 3/2 of 100 = 150% but you don't want to have bigger then your container.

You can find the source on github. At this point this is ONLY containing the grid itself. If you try to resize the window it will transform but not stacking. Let's keep that for the next episode.

PS: If you want you can use normalize.css or write your own reset but I think finding the right amount of tools is important and I think normalize.css is one of THE tools I suggest to use. (Bootstrap, Foundation and PureCSS do)

I hope it helped a bit. Next time I will explain the stacking and the media queries.

title: Build your own grid #2
content:
This is an episode of my "You might not need framework" series

Well last time we created the grid but it wasn't responsive at all. This time I added only a few simple trick using media queries (Media Queries for Standard Devices).
I also defined 3 stages, mobile, tablet and desktop so we can show and hide for the specific media.

/* For desktop */
@media (min-width: 992px) {
  .for-mobile,
  .for-tablet {
    display: none;
  }
}

/* For tablet */
@media (max-width: 991px) and (min-width: 769px) {
  .for-mobile,
  .for-desktop {
    display: none;
  }
}

The real trick starts here I reset the floating and change very unit to be 100% so it will stack to each other and fill the full with.

/* For mobile */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  [class*="u-"] {
    float: none;
    width: 100%;
    padding-right: 0;
    margin-left: 0;
  }

  .for-tablet,
  .for-desktop {
    display: none;
  }
}

We need offset as well. that will give as an empty unit. no trick here at all. Copy all the .u-X-Y then rename to .u-offset-X-Y or whatever you prefer. Then change width to margin-left. Keep the values. Job done! :)

.u-offset-1-2, .u-offset-2-4, .u-offset-3-6, .u-offset-4-8, .u-offset-5-10, .u-offset-6-12 { margin-left: 50%; }
.u-offset-1-3, .u-offset-2-6, .u-offset-3-9, .u-offset-4-12 { margin-left: 33.33333333%; }
.u-offset-1-4, .u-offset-2-8, .u-offset-3-12 { margin-left: 25%; }
.u-offset-1-5, .u-offset-2-10 { margin-left: 20%; }
.u-offset-1-6, .u-offset-2-12 { margin-left: 16.66666667%; }
.u-offset-1-7 { margin-left: 14.2857143%; }
.u-offset-1-8 { margin-left: 12.5%; }
.u-offset-1-9 { margin-left: 11.1111111%; }
.u-offset-1-10 { margin-left: 10%; }
.u-offset-1-11 { margin-left: 9.09090909%; }
.u-offset-1-12 { margin-left: 8.333333333%; }
.u-offset-2-3, .u-offset-4-6, .u-offset-6-9, .u-offset-8-12 { margin-left: 66.66666667%; }

As always the source is on GitHub

Next I will tame the forms.

title: Build your own tooltip
content:
This is an episode of my "You might not need framework" series

I like tooltips, they look really nice but do we really need to have as a Javascript plugin? Well yes if we want to remove the original title attribute but usually I don't have them on icons or buttons so I made a CSS only tooltip.

Apply on all class starting with do-tooltip (Read more about css do-*)
Then get attribute data-tooltip value and copy as a content after the element we're using.
:after contains the text :before is the arrow. (How to create CSS triangle)

[class*="do-tooltip"] {
  position: relative;
}

[class*="do-tooltip"]:after,
[class*="do-tooltip"]:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: none;
  z-index: 100;
}

[class*="do-tooltip"]:after {
  content: attr(data-tooltip);
  color: #fff;
  background: #333;
  font-family: sans-serif;
  font-size: 0.75em;
  padding: 5px 10px;
  text-align: center;
  white-space: nowrap;
}

[class*="do-tooltip"]:before {
  content: "";
  border: 6px solid;
}

[class*="do-tooltip"]:hover:after,
[class*="do-tooltip"]:hover:before {
  display: inline-block;
}

You can define now where to put the tooltip with classnames. If the class is without position it will use top. 

/* DEFAULT + TOP */
.do-tooltip:after,
.do-tooltip-top:after,
.do-tooltip:before,
.do-tooltip-top:before {
  bottom: 90%;
  left: -9999px;
  margin-bottom: 11px;
}

.do-tooltip:before,
.do-tooltip-top:before {
  border-color: #333 transparent transparent transparent;
  margin-bottom: 0;
}

.do-tooltip:hover:after,
.do-tooltip-top:hover:after {
  bottom: 100%;
  left: 0;
}

.do-tooltip:hover:before,
.do-tooltip-top:hover:before {
  bottom: 100%;
  left: 10px;
}

Right

/* RIGHT */
.do-tooltip-right:after,
.do-tooltip-right:before {
  top: -9999px;
  left: 96%;
  margin-left: 11px;
}

.do-tooltip-right:before {
  border-color: transparent #333 transparent transparent;
  margin-left: 0;
}

.do-tooltip-right:hover:after {
  top: -4px;
  left: 100%;
}

.do-tooltip-right:hover:before {
  top: 2px;
  left: 100%;
}

Bottom

/* BOTTOM */
.do-tooltip-bottom:after,
.do-tooltip-bottom:before {
  top: 90%;
  left: -9999px;
  margin-top: 11px;
}

.do-tooltip-bottom:before {
  border-color: transparent transparent #333 transparent;
  margin-top: 0;
}

.do-tooltip-bottom:hover:after {
  top: 100%;
  left: 0;
}

.do-tooltip-bottom:hover:before {
  top: 100%;
  left: 10px;
}

Left

/* LEFT */
.do-tooltip-left:after,
.do-tooltip-left:before {
  top: -9999px;
  right: 96%;
  margin-right: 11px;
}

.do-tooltip-left:before {
  border-color: transparent transparent transparent #333;
  margin-right: 0;
}

.do-tooltip-left:hover:after {
  top: -4px;
  right: 100%;
}

.do-tooltip-left:hover:before {
  top: 2px;
  right: 100%;
}

Probably it looks really strange but if you think about it then it is pretty straight forward. Only moving pixels to be aligned and have the right background color.

As last all you need to do now is to add it on an element

<a href="#" data-tooltip="Hello I am a tooltip" class="do-tooltip-right">Text</a>

title: Best backend
content:
I was thinking a lot what should be the best backend for my blog then after a bit of investigation I found the answer. The easiest, the fastest and the best(?). Do you need JSON for you javascript? Then just create a spreadsheet in Google Drive and publish to web and get the hashtag from the url and insert into this url: 

https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds/list/{{ HASH }}/od6/public/basic?hl=en_US&alt=json
There you go, you have a fully working backend in 1 line :)

In the last couple of weeks I read, learn and apply what I got. I have to say I feel more confident writing code than before.

(FYI as tools I meant tools are doing the just instead of you in your code not as tools like test or task runners)
I was obsessed with Karma (I still like it) but since I started using Mocha I don't understand why I haven't used it yet. So from now on I will stick with it.

Jiffy is a date manipulator lib. I am a big fan of moment.js so I decided to write my own date handler mini library. Check it out.

PS: I also made a few changes on this site. Now I load the posts from a CSV file from github and I made a lot of cleanup.

var csv2json = function(csv) {
  var ln = csv.split('\n');
  var result = [];
  var head = ln[0].split(',');

  for (var i = 1; i < ln.length; i++) {
    var obj = {};
    var cur = ln[i].split(',');

    for (var j = 0; j < head.length; j++) {
      obj[head[j]] = cur[j];
    }

    result.push(obj);
  }

  return result;
};
